doc.after: The original web-based Wikipedia editor provided by MediaWiki is a plain browser based[note 1] text editor where authors had to learn the wiki markup language to edit.[9] A WYSIWYG editor for Wikipedia has been planned for years in order to remove the need to learn the wiki markup language, thus reducing the technical hurdle for would-be Wikipedians, enabling wider participation in editing, and subsequently reversing the decline in editor numbers of 50,000 in 2006 to 35,000 in 2011, having peaked in 2007.[6][7] It was part a $1m project developing new features and making improvements.[6] An aim of the project is to allow both the former wiki markup editing and editing with the WYSIWYG VisualEditor.[10] According to Wikimedia Foundation's Jay Walsh, the hope is to redress under-represented contributions from Arabic, Portuguese, and Indic-language versions of the site.[7][note 2]
